awd_titl_txt: Development of Statistical Fault Detection Algorithms for Modern Power Grid Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
The national power grid has been undergoing transformational changes and facing new challenges over the last decade. The grid no longer consists of power suppliers, like coal, hydroelectric and nuclear plants, which supply power at a roughly constant rate. Renewable energy sources deliver power in a much less predictable manner due to their dependence on weather factors. Many retail and service facilities are no longer pure energy consumers but have become energy producers by installing large solar farms. In this new environment, it is important to develop new tools for timely detection of faults. Due to the less predictable power delivery and consumption, and possible attacks, fault detection must be based on the understanding of the random structure of the grid operation whose characteristics can be measured by a new generation of devices. These devices generate massive data sets, which have not yet been widely utilized. The PIs will address many specific questions related to the detection and identification of power grid faults. The PIs will use data obtained from modern measurements devices and develop state of the art statistical methodology. Advances made in this research will contribute to the energy security of the United States. The project will provide training to graduate and undergraduate students. 

The PIs will develop advanced statistical theory and large-scale computational tools that will form a foundation for engineering implementations aimed at detecting and identifying power grid faults. This will be done within a framework of change point detection methodology. Specifically, the PIs will 1) develop algorithms for screening sensor inputs that impact specific protection devices; 2) create algorithms for fault monitoring, with controlled significance level and expected time to detection; 3) develop theoretical and practical foundations for a posteriori change point testing in smart grid networks; 4) work out algorithms for the identification of subgrids affected by faults and the classification of faults; and 5) enhance PSCAD/EMTDC simulation tools by incorporating characteristics of high resolution sensor readings. It will be a collaborative effort combining the expertise of two statisticians working, respectively, in stochastic networks and large-scale computing (Wang) and time series analysis (Kokoszka), and a network engineer specializing in smart grids and signal processing (Yang).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We developed statistical and deep learning procedures for real time detection and localization of faults in a large regional power grid. As a testbed for our methodology we used a realistic computer model of the Western Interconnection that includes major transmission lines and  buses (grid nodes) corresponding to power generators and power consumers. The Western Interconnection covers the region west of the Great Plains  between the Mexican and Canadian borders. 

Faults in a power transmission grid can occur for a number of reasons. They typically occur when a line is damaged or incapacitated in some way, for example due to the failure of equipment or external impacts, like falling trees or large branches, or purposeful damage.  Faults can also occur at buses, for example when a generator fails. Our research was concerned with faults that occur at transmission lines because they cover large distances, often over sparsely inhabited areas, and can cause large fires. It is therefore important for electrical utility companies to be able to see immediately when a fault occurs and determine with reasonable confidence on which line it has occurred. We have developed and tested algorithms that can pinpoint the faulted line with well controlled confidence,  even if only some data are available. This means that our algorithms do not need all measurements that can be potentially generated, but only some of them. For example, they will work if only voltage measurements are available, and if they are available only at some, rather than all, buses. 

The measurements we used are those generated by state of the art Phasor Measurement Units that can report 120 measurements per second. Our collaborators at the University of Wyoming and the National Renewable Energy Laboratory employed most advanced computer simulators to help us create a database of thousands of faults that can be used by other researchers. Such a large database is needed to evaluate the success and failure rates of various methods and to train deep learning methods. 

The problems we were working on motivated new statistical theory and methodology published in a large number of statistics journals. Most advances were made in the areas of functional data analysis, spatial statistics, time series analysis, in particular change point detection and multivariate and contaminated data. 

In the course of the research supported by this award, we trained five PhD students and contributed to summer research opportunities for a large number of undergraduate students. 

This research has impact on power grid engineering in a sense that it may lead to the development of software that can be used to signal and locate a fault in a regional power grid almost immediately. Our work on detection based on streaming data may also be practically relevant. It shows what percentage of locations are needed to reliably detect a fault and avoid false alarms.  We have also shown how deep learning graphical networks can be constructed to reconstruct data at buses where data are for some reasons unavailable, e.g. due to natural disasters or cyberattacks. 

The new statistical methodology and theory will also have impact on many other fields where it is important to detect and localize some change, which does not necessarily have to be a power line fault. Some papers we published deal with applications to capital markets, climate science, epidemics and brain research.
